original_theorem:
If $P=\{a_{n_i}\}_1^\infty$ and
$Q=
\{a_{m_j}\}_1^\infty$ are respectively the subsequences of all
positive and
negative terms in a conditionally convergent series $\sum a_n,$ then
\begin{equation} \label{eq:4.3.24}
\sum_{i=1}^\infty a_{n_i}=\infty\mbox{\quad and\quad}\sum_{j=1}^\infty
a_{m_j}=-\infty.
\end{equation}
theorem_translation:
```lean4
theorem theorem_4_3_24 (a : ℕ → ℝ) (h_cond_conv : Summable a ∧ ¬  (Summable fun n => |a n|)) :
    (∃ (n_pos : ℕ → ℕ),
      StrictMono n_pos ∧ (∀ i, a (n_pos i) > 0) ∧ (Tendsto (fun N => ∑ i in Finset.range N, a (n_pos i)) atTop atTop)) ∧
    (∃ (n_neg : ℕ → ℕ),
      StrictMono n_neg ∧ (∀ i, a (n_neg i) < 0) ∧ (Tendsto (fun N => ∑ i in Finset.range N, a (n_neg i)) atTop atBot)) := by
```

import Mathlib
import Aesop

set_option maxHeartbeats 0
open BigOperators Real Nat Topology Rat Filter
theorem theorem_4_3_24 (a : ℕ → ℝ) (h_cond_conv : Summable a ∧ ¬  (Summable fun n => |a n|)) :
    (∃ (n_pos : ℕ → ℕ),
      StrictMono n_pos ∧ (∀ i, a (n_pos i) > 0) ∧ (Tendsto (fun N => ∑ i in Finset.range N, a (n_pos i)) atTop atTop)) ∧
    (∃ (n_neg : ℕ → ℕ),
      StrictMono n_neg ∧ (∀ i, a (n_neg i) < 0) ∧ (Tendsto (fun N => ∑ i in Finset.range N, a (n_neg i)) atTop atBot)) := by sorry

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• Let $\{a_n\}$ be a sequence of real numbers, with its subsequence of positive terms being $P=\{a_{n_i}\}_{i=1}^\infty$ and its subsequence of negative terms being $Q=\{a_{m_j}\}_{j=1}^\infty$ [from tc_1].
• The series of positive terms converges: $\sum_{i=1}^\infty a_{n_i} = L_P$.
• The series of negative terms converges: $\sum_{j=1}^\infty a_{m_j} = L_Q$.
Therefore, we conclude:
• The series $\sum a_n$ converges absolutely [l1].
proof_steps.lean_tactics: have h_abs_series_converges : Summable fun n => |a n| := by sorry

    (∃ (n_pos : ℕ → ℕ),
      StrictMono n_pos ∧ (∀ i, a (n_pos i) > 0) ∧ (Tendsto (fun N => ∑ i in Finset.range N, a (n_pos i)) atTop atTop)) ∧
    (∃ (n_neg : ℕ → ℕ),

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• Let $\{a_n\}$ be a sequence of real numbers, with its subsequence of positive terms being $P=\{a_{n_i}\}_{i=1}^\infty$ and its subsequence of negative terms being $Q=\{a_{m_j}\}_{j=1}^\infty$ [from tc_1].
• One of the series, $\sum a_{n_i}$ or $\sum a_{m_j}$, converges to a finite limit, while the other diverges.
Therefore, we conclude:
• The series $\sum a_n$ diverges to $\infty$ or $-\infty$ [l2].
proof_steps.lean_tactics: sorry  -- skipped due to previous failure

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• For a series $\sum a_n$ with positive part $\sum a_{n_i}$ and negative part $\sum a_{m_j}$: the series $\sum a_n$ is conditionally convergent, meaning it converges but not absolutely [tc_1].
• If both $\sum a_{n_i}$ and $\sum a_{m_j}$ converge, then $\sum a_n$ converges absolutely [l1].
• If one of $\sum a_{n_i}$ or $\sum a_{m_j}$ converges and the other diverges, then $\sum a_n$ diverges to $\pm\infty$ [l2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• Both $\sum a_{n_i}$ and $\sum a_{m_j}$ must diverge. Since all terms in $\{a_{n_i}\}$ are positive, its sum must diverge to $\infty$. Since all terms in $\{a_{m_j}\}$ are negative, its sum must diverge to $-\infty$ [ts_1].
proof_steps.lean_tactics: sorry  -- skipped due to previous failure
